title: Recognize positive and thank-you words in chat responses

requirements.text: Update the Motoko backend `answerQuestion(question : Text)` handler to recognize common positive/thank-you words and return an appropriate friendly response when they appear in the user input (e.g., "nice", "good", "excellent", "great", "thanks", and similar variants). Matching must be case-insensitive and work when the word appears alone or inside a longer sentence.

quotes: it needs to understand words like  nice , good ,excellent, great , thanks e.t.c

acceptanceCriteria: When the user submits exactly "thanks" (any casing, e.g., "Thanks", "THANKS"), the canister returns a friendly acknowledgment (e.g., "You're welcome!" or "Glad I could help!").
When the user submits a longer message containing one of the positive/thank-you words (e.g., "That was excellent, thanks"), the canister matches it and returns the same acknowledgment response.
When the user submits punctuation-adjacent forms (e.g., "thanks!", "great."), the canister still matches and responds.
Existing topic-specific responses (cost, privacy, ICP, science, etc.) continue to work as before.

requirements.text: Add at least one example prompt in the chat UI to demonstrate the new positive/thank-you word recognition (e.g., add "Thanks" or "Great job" to the example prompt list).

quotes: it needs to understand words like  nice , good ,excellent, great , thanks e.t.c

acceptanceCriteria: The welcome-state example prompt buttons include a new prompt that uses a positive/thank-you phrase.
Clicking the new example prompt button fills the input field with that phrase, consistent with existing example prompt behavior.

constraints: Backend must remain a single Motoko actor in `backend/main.mo` (no additional backend services).
Do not edit any frontend files under `frontend/src/components/ui` or any other paths listed as immutable in SYSTEM_CONTEXT.
nonGoals: Implementing full sentiment analysis, ML/NLP, or scoring; only keyword/phrase recognition is required.
Adding third-party integrations or external APIs for language understanding.
